item.title: What Happened on Day 76 of the War in Ukraine
item.description: The Russian military, despite missteps, has gained near total control of the Donbas region.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dozens of open graves at a military cemetery in the eastern city of Dnipro on Tuesday. More than 400 Ukrainian soldiers killed since Russia’s February invasion have been buried there.

item.title: Philippines Election: Marcos Win Draws Protests
item.description: Young voters who had rallied around Leni Robredo during the presidential race gathered to voice their frustration with preliminary results showing her overwhelming defeat.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.media:credit: Jes Aznar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Young voters protesting election fraud in Manila on Tuesday. For many Filipinos, the Marcos family name remains a byword for excess and greed.

item.title: How Maria Alyokhina of Pussy Riot Escaped From Russia
item.description: After more than a decade of activism, Maria Alyokhina disguised herself as a food courier to evade the police — and a widening crackdown by President Vladimir Putin.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins and Misha Friedman
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Misha Friedman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Maria V. Alyokhina in Iceland's National Theater in Reykjavik. “I still don’t understand completely what I’ve done,” she said.

item.title: South Korea Inaugurates Yoon Suk-yeol as President
item.description: During his inaugural speech, Yoon Suk-yeol said his country would play a greater role in promoting freedom and human rights around the world.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Yoon Suk-yeol, South Korea’s new president, at his inauguration in front of the Congress Building in Seoul on Tuesday.

item.title: Crowdfunding a War: How Online Appeals Are Bringing Weapons to Ukraine
item.description: A campaign to crowdfund donations and weapons is producing millions of dollars as well as a bounty of smaller weapons and other military equipment for the Ukrainian military.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times

item.title: Ferdinand Marcos Jr. Is Bound for Presidency of the Philippines
item.description: Early counting put Mr. Marcos, the son and namesake of the country’s former dictator, more than 15 million votes ahead of his top presidential rival in one of the country’s most consequential elections in decades.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Jes Aznar for The New York Times
item.media:description: A line at a polling station in Manila, on Monday.

item.title: Charles Gives Queen’s Speech at State Opening of Parliament in U.K.
item.description: For only the third time in 70 years, Elizabeth was unable to deliver her speech at the State Opening of Parliament. The palace said she had been having trouble walking; Prince Charles stood in.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Arthur Edwards
item.media:description: Prince Charles, heir to the British throne, delivering the Queen’s Speech during the State Opening of Parliament in London on Tuesday.

item.title: For French Military, War in Ukraine Prompts a Shift in Focus
item.description: While it is in Europe’s interest to weaken Moscow, the chief of staff of France’s military says, Russia may someday need to play a part in a global security plan.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Benoit Tessier/Reuters
item.media:description: French soldiers from the 7th Battalion of Chasseurs Alpins taking part in a drill at the NATO military base in Tapa, Estonia, in March.

item.title: U.K. Labour Leader Pledges to Resign if Police Find He Broke Covid Rules
item.description: But Keir Starmer maintained that he was within the law when he had a beer with takeout food during a campaign meeting last year.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Neil Hall/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Keir Starmer, the leader of the opposition Labour Party in Britain, leaving his home in north London on Monday.

item.title: In Photos: Russia Celebrates Victory Day Holiday With Parade in Red Square
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin used his speech on Russia’s most important secular holiday to rally support for the country’s invasion of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Alexander Zemlianichenko/Associated Press

item.title: Ecuador Prison Riot Leaves Dozens Dead
item.description: The riot in northern Ecuador left at least 40 inmates dead and more than a dozen injured. It’s the latest blood bath inside the country’s troubled and overcrowded prison system.
item.dc:creator: Oscar Lopez
item.media:credit: Juan Carlos Perez/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A wounded inmate being transported from a truck to an ambulance after a riot at the Social Bellavista prison in Santo Domingo, Ecuador, on Monday.

item.title: Sri Lanka’s Prime Minister Mahinda Rajapaksa Resigns in Face of Unrest
item.description: The move by Mahinda Rajapaksa came after his supporters instigated violent clashes in Colombo, the capital. It wasn’t immediately clear whether his resignation would satisfy opponents.
item.dc:creator: Skandha Gunasekara and Mujib Mashal
item.media:credit: Ishara S. Kodikara/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Government supporters and opponents clashed Monday outside the official residence of Prime Minister Mahinda Rajapaksa in Colombo, Sri Lanka.

item.title: In Europe’s Schoolyards, Putin’s War Hurts Russian-Speaking Children
item.description: Across the continent, pupils face bullying, harassment and humiliation over the invasion of Ukraine, another perverse effect of a war that is overwhelmingly affecting the innocent.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola and Valeriya Safronova
item.media:credit: Lena Mucha for The New York Times
item.media:description: Alex Ebert taking a public bus to school this month in a suburb of Aachen, Germany. He was attacked on the bus returning home in March.

item.title: Biden Speeds Up Military Aid to Ukraine, Drawing U.S. Deeper Into War
item.description: President Biden signed the Lend-Lease Act, which will waive time-consuming requirements on the provision of arms to Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker and Emily Cochrane
item.media:credit: Cheriss May for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden signing the Ukraine Democracy Defense Lend-Lease Act on Monday at the White House. He has tried to back Ukraine while avoiding giving the impression that the United States is in a proxy war.

item.title: Al Jazeera Journalist Is Killed During Clashes in West Bank
item.description: The circumstances surrounding the fatal shooting of Shireen Abu Akleh, a veteran journalist, are still unclear.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:credit: Jaafar Ashtiyeh/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Journalists escorting the body of Shireen Abu Akleh, a journalist who was fatally shot early Wednesday while covering a clash in the West Bank city of Jenin.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Russian advances in eastern Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Valentina led her blind mother, Nina, aboard an evacuation train in Pokrovsk, in the Donbas region of Ukraine.

item.title: Leonid Kravchuk, First President of Ukraine, Dies at 88
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil
item.media:credit: Olena Khudiakova/Future Publishing, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Leonid Kravchuk on Jan. 10, 2019, his 85th birthday, in Kyiv, Ukraine.

item.title: Iran Says It Will Execute Ahmadreza Djalali, Swedish-Iranian Accused of Spying
item.description: Ahmadreza Djalali denies he spied for Israel or helped it kill Iranian nuclear scientists.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Tino Romano/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: A protest in Turin, Italy, in 2020 against Iran sentencing an Iranian-Swedish doctor, Ahmadreza Djalali, to death.

item.title: Russia Was Behind Cyberattack in Run-Up to Ukraine War, Investigation Finds
item.description: The February attack rattled Pentagon officials and private industry because it revealed new vulnerabilities in global communications systems.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Kate Conger
item.media:credit: Mikhail Metzel/Sputnik
item.media:description: Investigators said the Russian military intelligence agency took satellite communications in Ukraine offline. The attack came before the Feb. 24 invasion launched by President Vladimir V. Putin.

item.title: Ukraine War’s Geographic Reality: Russia Has Seized Much of the East
item.description: Despite many stumbles and setbacks, the Russian military has gained near total control of the Donbas region, giving the Kremlin huge leverage in any future talks.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz, Marc Santora and Michael Levenson
item.category: European Bank for Reconstruction and Development
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Boarding an evacuation train at the Pokrovsk train station on Tuesday in the Donbas region of Ukraine.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: South Korea’s New President
item.description: Plus protests in the Philippines and a weakened Japanese yen.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Yoon Suk-yeol, South Korea’s new president, at his inauguration.

item.title: Spain’s Intelligence Leader Ousted Over Agency’s Use of Pegasus Spyware
item.description: Paz Esteban, the first woman to hold the job, was caught up in a scandal over her agency’s use of Pegasus spyware.
item.dc:creator: Raphael Minder
item.media:credit: Juan Carlos Hidalgo/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Paz Esteban, the chief of Spain’s intelligence service, arriving last week to appear before a parliamentary committee to discuss how her agency had used Israeli spyware on the phones of Catalan politicians.

item.title: Vardy and Rooney ‘Wagatha Christie’ Trial Begins in London
item.description: A public spat between the famous wives of two English soccer players, which has riveted tabloid attention in Britain, will be decided in court.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Peter Nicholls/Reuters
item.media:description: Rebekah Vardy, wife of the Leicester City soccer player Jamie Vardy, arriving at court in London on Tuesday.

item.title: Francis Fukuyama Predicted the End of History. It’s Back (Again).
item.description: In a new book, the political theorist offers a stout defense of liberalism against threats from left and right — and predicts that Ukraine will revive “the spirit of 1989.”
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Schuessler
item.media:credit: Jim McAuley for The New York Times
item.media:description: The politial scientist Francis Fukuyama in his office at Stanford University. “There’s been so much cynicism about democracy, including in democratic countries,” he said.

item.title: Afghans Urge Court Not to Give Frozen Central Bank Assets to Sept. 11 Families
item.description: Advocates for the Afghan people say it would be unjust and illegal to use $3.5 billion of Afghanistan’s assets to pay off the Taliban’s judgment debts.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Huge crowds last year outside the Azizi Bank main branch in Kabul, Afghanistan, after the Taliban swept the country.

item.title: As Shanghai’s Covid Cases Fall, China’s Restrictions Tighten
item.description: Schools are closed indefinitely in Beijing, while the last subway lines in Shanghai that were still running have ceased operation.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson
item.media:credit: Aly Song/Reuters
item.media:description: Workers enter a residential area in Shanghai on Monday.

item.title: How Much of Ukraine Does Russia Hold?
item.description: Although Russian forces failed to take Kyiv, they have captured large chunks of the south and east, giving Moscow a chance to strangle the country economically.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: A World War II memorial in Kyiv on Sunday.

item.title: How Public Services Are Operating in Ukraine
item.description: Our reporters answer readers’ questions about Russia’s invasion of Ukraine. Many of you asked about schools and hospitals.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Natalia Arkhipova, a head nurse at a military hospital in Zaporizhzhia, Ukraine, rests after a series of long days treating injured soldiers in April.

item.title: ‘They are really on the last breath’: The wives of soldiers in Mariupol plead for help.
item.description: Interviews and public comments by the spouses of soldiers holed up in a steel plant in the southern Ukrainian city paint a grim picture of the fighters’ situation.
item.dc:creator: Maria Varenikova and Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Alessandra Tarantino/Associated Press
item.media:description: Kateryna Prokopenko, right, and Yulia Fedosiuk with photographs of their husbands in Rome last month.

item.title: On the Phone, Alone
item.description: We look at the mental health crisis facing adolescents — and the role of digital technology.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Annie Flanagan for The New York Times

item.title: Teens in Distress Are Swamping Pediatricians
item.description: Around the country, the setting for adolescent mental health care looks ever more like this doctor’s office in Kentucky, the next patient arriving every 15 minutes.
item.dc:creator: Matt Richtel and Annie Flanagan

item.title: Oil Giants Sell Dirty Wells to Buyers With Looser Climate Goals, Study Finds
item.description: The transactions can help major oil and gas companies clean up their own production by transferring polluting assets to a different firm, the analysis said.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:credit: Sunday Alamba/Associated Press
item.media:description: Flares burning in the Niger Delta region of Nigeria in 2021.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Putin’s Victory Day speech.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Maxim Shipenkov/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Vladimir Putin entering the Red Square to attend the Victory Day parade.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: A Marcos Victory?
item.description: Plus the resignation of Sri Lanka’s prime minister and Taiwan’s pandemic pivot.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Jes Aznar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ferdinand Marcos Jr., the son of the former dictator who was ousted 36 years ago, addressed his supporters during a campaign rally in March.

item.title: Former Heads of State Call on U.S. to Commit $5 Billion for Global Covid Aid
item.description: Activists are also pressing President Biden to take a more forceful leadership role in the response as he convenes world leaders for a Covid-19 summit on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden delivering remarks on the status of the country’s fight against Covid-19 at the White House in March.

item.title: Biden Signs Lend-Lease Act, Speeding Up Weapons Shipments to Ukraine
item.description: The law will waive time-consuming requirements on the provision of arms to Ukraine considered critical to its defense against Russian forces.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:credit: Cheriss May for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden signing the Ukraine Democracy Defense Lend-Lease Act on Monday at the White House. He has tried to back Ukraine while avoiding giving the impression that the United States is in a proxy war.

item.title: Queen Elizabeth to Miss Opening of Parliament
item.description: Prince Charles will deliver the Queen’s Speech instead of his mother, who has missed the constitutional monarchy’s powerful symbol only twice in 70 years.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Chris Jackson
item.media:description: Queen Elizabeth II reading the Queen's Speech during the opening of Parliament last year.

item.title: Macron Calls for ‘Stronger’ Europe but Quashes Ukraine’s Hopes of Joining E.U. Soon
item.description: French president Emmanuel Macron spoke in Strasbourg and Berlin on Monday, outlining proposals to reform the European Union.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Ludovic Marin
item.media:description: France’s President Emmanuel Macron in Strasbourg, eastern France, on Monday.

item.title: In Victory Day Speech, Putin Told Russians What He Wanted Them to Hear
item.description: The Russian president, in a much-anticipated speech on his country’s most important holiday, did not proclaim an escalation of the fight in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Maxim Shemetov/Reuters

item.title: Russia’s Invasion Upends Shared Victory Day History With Ukraine
item.description: The war has complicated relationships between Russians and Ukrainians.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nina Mikhailovna laid flowers on Monday at the Kramatorsk World War II memorial on the anniversary of the Soviet Union’s victory over the Nazis, as explosions thundered nearby in the Donbas region of Ukraine.

item.title: U.S. to Lift Tariffs on Ukrainian Steel
item.description: The Biden administration will lift a 25 percent tariff on the Ukrainian steel sector for one year to help the country’s economy.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: The ArcelorMittal plant in Kryvyi Rih, Ukraine. The steel sector is a significant source of economic growth and employment for Ukraine.

item.title: ‘‘It’s not over yet’’: Way ahead in early counting, Ferdinand Marcos Jr. remains cautious.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.media:credit: Lauren Decicca/Getty Images
item.media:description: Ferdinand Marcos Jr. heading to vote in Batac, Philippines, on Monday.

item.title: Voters complain of broken machines and long waits.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee and Camille Elemia
item.media:credit: Jes Aznar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Voting in Manila on Monday.

item.title: Appease or Confront
item.description: It’s Victory Day in Russia — a holiday honoring World War II that has long been important to Vladimir Putin.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pro-Putin flags in Moscow in 2014.

item.title: A Woman Alone in Oman: Three Weeks Along the Arabian Coast
item.description: In December, a photographer set off on a 2,600-mile road trip, traveling from the Yemeni border to the Strait of Hormuz. Here’s what she saw.
item.dc:creator: Noa Avishag Schnall
item.media:credit: Noa Avishag Schnall
item.media:description: Dromedaries graze in the marsh where fresh water from Wadi Ashawq meets the Arabian Sea.

item.title: Taiwan Pivots From ‘Zero Covid’ as Beijing Doubles Down
item.description: The government’s shift reflects a recognition that stringent pandemic measures were stifling economic activity and eroding the island’s international competitiveness.
item.dc:creator: Amy Qin, Amy Chang Chien and Isabelle Qian
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: A wet market in New Taipei City, Taiwan. The government’s shift in Covid strategy is partly out of necessity. The island risks losing out on tourism and investment by staying closed.

item.title: Two political clans with an autocratic past seek power together.
item.dc:creator: Richard C. Paddock
item.media:credit: Ezra Acayan for The New York Times
item.media:description: A farmer carries a sack of rice next to a mobile rice mill adorned with a campaign poster for Ferdinand “Bongbong” Marcos Jr. and Sara Duterte, in Nueva Ecija Province in May.

item.title: Young Filipinos Embrace Leni Robredo, Sole Woman in Presidential Race
item.description: “Generation Z” and thousands of millennial voters drew inspiration from her effort to take on Ferdinand Marcos Jr.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.media:credit: Jes Aznar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Leni Robredo at a March campaign event in Pasig City.

item.title: Reports of Violence Leave Philippines Voters on Edge
item.description: Security was tight for this election, a particularly high-stakes contest that some observers have called an existential battle for the soul of the nation.
item.dc:creator: Jason Gutierrez
item.media:credit: Jes Aznar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Police officers on Monday near a polling station in Manila. Violence is common during Philippine elections, and the government has deployed more than 250,000 police and military personnel to prevent it.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Commemorations against a backdrop of war.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: A World War II memorial in Kyiv on Sunday, a Ukrainian holiday known as the Day of Remembrance and Reconciliation.

item.title: Ferdinand Marcos Jr., Late Dictator’s Son, May Lead the Philippines
item.description: Ferdinand Marcos Jr. has spent decades defending his family’s name against accusations of corruption and downplaying his father’s brutal regime.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.media:credit: Jes Aznar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ferdinand Marcos Jr. addressing his supporters during a campaign rally in March.
